Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Using Micro-Nano-Fabrication Technology to Pattern Conductive Polymer Electrodes on Flexible Membranes

POR.DRECONTENT:
I collaborated with the Information Storage Materials Laboratory at the National University of Singapore under the direction of Professor Adekunle O. Adeyeye on using Micro-Nano-Fabrication techniques, particularly deep ultraviolet optical projection lithography, to pattern large-area magnetic nanostructures on silicon substrates. These features were patterned using resolution enhancement techniques such as chromeless, attenuated, and alternating phase shift masks in order to the push the limit of resolvable features due to diffraction. I explored these techniques for future work in patterning conductive polymer electrodes on flexible membranes, as well as patterning of nanowires for applications in biosensors. I simulated my structures using LLG Micromagnetics Simulator software package and characterized my devices by atomic force microscopy, magnetic force microscopy, magneto-optic Kerr effect, and scanning electron microscopy.

I studied the magnetic spin states of the nanostructures by applying an external magnetic field and measuring the magnetization of the devices. I varied the magnetic material, thickness, and geometry of the nanostructures and observed the effect of the magnetization and magnetic spin states of the devices in the presence of varying external magnetic fields. These substrates are being used to explore signal enhancement mechanisms for spectroscopic studies and the development of an impedance tomography device for non-invasive body fluid imaging.


Last Modified: 12/01/2010
Modified by: Yemaya C Bordain
